title: Derivation of Induced Pluripotent Stem Cells from Human Fibroblasts Using a Non-integrative System in Feeder-free Conditions
procedures: Day -1: Plate dermal fibroblast for reprogrammingUse low-passage (passage 1 to 5) human fibroblasts for reprogramming experiments. The reprogramming efficiency decreases with each passage. Hence, we don’t recommend reprogramming fibroblast after passage 6. A schematic timeline and representative pictures can be seen in Figure 1. Coat two wells of a 6 well plate with 2 ml of 5 mg/ml Matrigel and make sure it covers the entire well. Incubate at 37 °C for 30 min. Inspect the fibroblast culture for the desired confluency (more than 70%), aspirate the culture medium and rinse twice with 2 ml DPBS. Add 500 µl TrypLETM Express enzyme and incubate at 37 °C and 5% CO2 for 2 to 5 min or until fibroblasts have detached. TrypLETM is used because it has lower cell toxicity than standard Trypsin and it is an animal-free product. Add 1 ml fibroblast culture medium and transfer cell suspension to a 15-ml conical tube. Centrifuge at 200 x g for 5 min. Remove and discard supernatant. Resuspend cells in 1 ml of fresh fibroblast culture medium. Recipe available in the recipe section. Count fibroblasts using the desired method (e.g., Countess Automated Cell Counter), and plate 1 x 105 cells/well (10,000 cells/cm2) in the Matrigel-coated 6-well dish in 2 ml of fibroblast culture medium. Incubate 24 h at 37 °C with a humidified atmosphere and 5% CO2.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20201015/20201015195516_1080.jpgFigure 1. Derivation of induced pluripotent stem cells from fibroblast using Sendai virus and chemically defined medium. A. Schematic view of general reprogramming procedure including culture medium used. B. Images of fibroblast morphology changes during the early stages of reprogramming. Scale bars: 650 μm.Day 0: Transduction  Inspect the fibroblast culture, proceed with transduction if cell density is approximately 40-50% confluent, and cells have fully adhered and extended.

If those parameters are not meet, wait another 24 h. Warm 1 ml of fibroblast culture medium in a water bath for each well to be transduced calculate the volume of each premade virus needed to reach a multiplicity of infection of (MOI) of 5:5:3 (KOS MOI = 5, hc-Myc MOI = 5, hKlf4 MOI = 3) using the live cell count from the day of the seeding, and the titer information on the CoA (calculate based on the lot number, the CoA can be download from thermofisher.com/cytotune). Calculate the volume of virus using the formula:imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20201015/20201015204211_1805.jpg CIU = Cell infectious unitsFor example, to calculate the volume of hKOS virus with a titter of 1.1 x 108 CIU;imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20201015/20201015204502_8935.jpgThaw one set of CytoTuneTM 2.0 Sendai aliquots from -80 °C and briefly centrifuge the tube. Place it immediately on ice until ready to use. Add the calculated volumes of each of the three CytoTuneTM 2.0 Sendai virus to 1 ml of pre-warmed fibroblast culture medium. OPTIONAL: Add 4 μg/ml of polybrene to the medium. Ensure that the solution of virus and polybrene is thoroughly mixed by pipetting the mixture gently up and down. Complete the next step within 5 min.Polybrene increases the transduction efficiency of the virus, however, it can be toxic for some cell types. It neutralizes the charge repulsion between the virus and the cell surface increasing the overall transduction efficiency. Aspirate the fibroblast culture medium from the cells, and add the reprogramming virus and polybrene mixture to the well containing the cells. Close the 6-well dish, securely place on the plate adaptor, and centrifuge at 1,200 x g for 45 min at room temperature. Once the centrifugation is complete, add an additional 1 ml of prewarm fibroblast culture medium.

Incubate the plate overnight in a 37 °C incubator with a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2.Day 1: Remove virusAfter 24 h, aspirate medium with viruses and add 2 ml fresh fibroblast culture medium. Expect to see cytotoxicity 24-48 h post-transduction, this is an indication of high uptake of the virus. See Figure 2.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20201015/20201015200020_3968.jpgFigure 2. Images of morphological changes seventy-two hours after transduction with Sendai virus. Scale bars: 650 μm.Days 2 to 3Remove 2 ml of used medium and add 2 ml of fibroblast culture medium. Expect to see changes in cell morphology.Day 4: Transition to defined mediumThere are many different chemically defined culture medium commercially available for deriving and maintaining iPSCs. We have used mTeSR1 medium (Stem Cell Technologies), STEMFLEX (Life technologies) and mTeSR plus (Stem Cell Technologies) agnostically. Remove 500 μl of fibroblast culture medium and add 500 μl of fresh mTeSR1.Day 5 Remove 1 ml of culture medium and add 1 ml of fresh mTeSR1.Day 6 Remove 1.5 ml of culture medium and add 1.5 ml of fresh mTeSR1.Day 7Remove 2 ml of medium culture medium and add the same volume of fresh mTeSR1.Days 8-20Feed cells daily with 2 ml until colonies are ready to be passaged. Remove partially reprogrammed and differentiated colonies by scraping them before medium change. Fully reprogrammed colonies have round shape with well-defined borders, cells display identical morphology with a high ratio of nucleus to cytoplasm and prominent nucleoli. In contrast, partially reprogrammed colonies have undefined borders, an amorphous shape, and are composed of different types of cells.Day 21: First passage When colonies are ready to pick, prepare one Matrigel coated dish per colony to be passage, and incubate at 37 °C for at least 30 min.Aspirate Matrigel from plates and add 2 ml mTeSR1 + 10 µM ROCK inhibitor.

Use a 22 gauge needle or a pulled glass pipette to cut colonies in a grid-like pattern into small fragments. See Figure 3.Use a 100 µl pipettor to scrape fragments and collect them. Immediately transfer the fragments to the Matrigel coated plates with mTeSR1 + 10 µM ROCK inhibitor.Rock plate back-and-forth and side-to-side to evenly distribute the cell fragments and incubate overnight at 37 °C with a humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2.Feed cells daily until ready to passage (usually every 6 to 7 days).Repeat Steps 1 to 10 for 7 passages. We found that > 95% of the iPSCs clones at passage 7, are transgene free.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20201015/20201015200836_3694.jpgFigure 3. Images of colonies cut in a grid-like pattern into small fragments. Scale bars: 650 μm.IPSCs cloning and expansionAfter passage 7, IPSCs are passage with EDTA buffer, as follow: Coat 6 wells of a 6-well tissue culture plate with Matrigel and place in incubate at 37 °C for 30 min.Prior to use, allow the Matrigel-coated plate to equilibrate to room temperature for at least 1 h.Just before dissociating cells for passaging, aspirate the liquid Matrigel solution from the wells and replace with 1 ml of mTeSR1 + 10mM Y27632 cell culture media per well. Set aside.Wash the cells with 2 ml 0.5 mM EDTA, aspirate.Add 2 ml of room temperature 0.5 mM EDTA solution to the cells.Incubate the culture at 37 °C for 3 to 5 min, or until cells begin to separate uniformly throughout the entire colony. Do not allow the cultures detach in the EDTA solution.As soon as the cells appear rounded and uniform separation is seen throughout the colonies, carefully aspirate the EDTA solution from the well. Do not rinse.Immediately add 1 ml of mTeSR1 + 10mM Y27632.

With a 5 ml pipet, take up the 1 ml of media from the well, and very gently dispense it against the culture surface to dissociate the cells from the dish. Repeat 1 to 2 more times, if needed.Be careful not to over-pipet the cell suspension.Dispense the cells gently into the 15 ml conical tube containing an additional 3 ml of pre-warmed media.Pipet the solution very gently 1 time to mix, and dispense 1 ml of the cell suspension drop-wise into each of the 6 new Matrigel-coated wells, and immediately rock plate back-and-forth and side-to-side to evenly distribute the colony pieces across the well.Incubate undisturbed at 37 °C and 5% CO2 overnight.Replace cell culture media every day with 2.5 ml of fresh mTeSR1, warmed to room temperature.Monitor cells daily and passage as needed.Characterization and cryopreservationCells are expanded for cryopreservation at passage 10. Then, iPSCs are characterized (Figure 4) and prepare for downstream usage in genome engineering experiments or differentiation into specific cell types. Characterization includes: Immunofluorescence staining of cell surface markers such Anti-Human TRA-1-60, Mouse monoclonal and transcription factors such as anti-Human OCT4, Rabbit polyclonal, IgG1 and anti-Human SOX2 Antibody, Rabbit polyclonal IgG1.Pluripotency and trilineage differentiation capabilities (using the STEMdiff Trilineage Differentiation kit, and the Taqman hPSC Score card Panel.Test for mycoplasma contamination using commercially available kits such as The Universal Mycoplasma Detection Kit.G-banding Karyotype.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/20201015/20201015201302_9532.jpgFigure 4. Characterization of iPSC derived from fibroblast. A. Bright field images of iPSCs, B. Immunofluorescence staining for pluripotency markers Tra-1-60 and OCT4. C. Taqman ScoreCard assay for pluripotent iPSCs (left panel) and iPSCs differentiated into endoderm, mesoderm and ectoderm (right panel). D. G-banding karyotype.
